channel.title: BBC News - Home

item.title: Afghanistan crisis: Unclear if ruthless Taliban will change, says US general
item.description: General Mark Milley says it "remains to be seen" whether the Islamist group will change.

item.title: Afghanistan: British passport delay blamed for baby stranded in Kabul
item.description: "We want to hug her, kiss her", say her parents, who had to return to the UK to replace travel documents.

item.title: Afghanistan: Unknown number of people left behind in Afghanistan, says Dominic Raab
item.description: The UK was "caught out" by the fall of Kabul, says the foreign secretary, who will travel to the region later.

item.title: Third Covid jab advised for most vulnerable 1%
item.description: More than 400,000 people in the UK are eligible - but plans for further boosters are yet to be confirmed.

item.title: McDonald’s hiring 14 year-olds in Oregon amid labour shortage
item.description: An Oregon branch sees flood of applications after failing to recruit older workers.

item.title: Ronaldo breaks men's international goal record
item.description: Cristiano Ronaldo breaks the world record for goals scored in men's international football with two headers against the Republic of Ireland.

item.title: Scots to need vaccine passports for large events
item.description: People who have not been fully vaccinated will not be able to attend many sporting events, concerts or nightclubs.

item.title: Syed Ali Geelani: Kashmir's separatist patriarch dies aged 92
item.description: Veteran separatist leader Syed Ali Geelani, a staunch critic of India, had been under house arrest.

item.title: Wetherspoons runs low on beer amid driver shortage
item.description: The pub chain and a Coca-Cola bottler are among firms affected by a shortage of UK lorry drivers.

item.title: Portugal changes vaccine rules for UK visitors
item.description: UK visitors no longer need to quarantine for 14 days if they can't prove they are fully vaccinated.

item.title: Maddie Durdant-Hollamby: Woman found in house was stabbed to death
item.description: Maddie Durdant-Hollamby was stabbed while Benjamin Green's injuries were self-inflicted, police say.

item.title: Long Covid in children 'nowhere near scale feared'
item.description: Public should be reassured over rates of persistent symptoms, leading child health experts say.

item.title: Declan Donnelly: Men admit plot to steal presenter's car
item.description: The group of four admit they had planned to steal about £750,000 worth of high-value vehicles.

item.title: The Papers: Ministers 'at war' - and call for more booster jabs
item.description: The papers report on a "blame game" over Afghanistan and calls for more adults to get an extra Covid jab.

item.title: Creamfields: Tiesto fan's ashes fired from confetti cannon in headline set
item.description: A celebration of Stuart Mitchell's life ended with his ashes being released during Tiesto's set.

item.title: West Sussex foster couple cared for more than 600 children
item.description: Pauline and Roger Fitter say watching the results of their efforts has been very rewarding.

item.title: Banksy-painted building in Lowestoft adds £200k to asking price
item.description: The old electrical shop is now up for sale at £500,000 after Banksy confirmed the art was genuine.

item.title: Majestic birds caught by the camera
item.description: A selection of the winners in this year's Bird Photographer of the Year competition.

item.title: Family of ducks waddles through University of Nottingham library
item.description: The mother and her ducklings were "calm and unflustered" as they walked around George Green Library.

item.title: Fresh Prince of Bel-Air: Will Smith reveals who will play him in show reboot
item.description: Newcomer Jabari Banks will take on the role in the upcoming NBC Peacock reboot of the hit 1990s show.

item.title: Second 10ft python spotted roaming Cambridgeshire village
item.description: The reptile is rescued close to where another was found four days earlier, the RPSCA says.

item.title: Why was this athlete 'too tall' to race?
item.description: Blake Leeper fought to compete with able-bodied athletes, but his blades were deemed too long.

item.title: Drugs: The county lines gang in our Powys cul-de-sac
item.description: What happens when drug dealers move in to a small, rural town?

item.title: Hurricane Ida: Before and after images reveal devastation
item.description: Aerial photographs reveal damage and flooding in parts of Louisiana following Hurricane Ida.

item.title: Texas abortion law: What women make of six-week abortion ban
item.description: Anti-abortion activists celebrate but a doctor who could be targeted by new law fears for the future.

item.title: Mr Zelensky (finally) goes to Washington
item.description: The Ukrainian president pressed by Donald Trump gets his White House visit - and a new set of worries.

item.title: Gulf Sky: 'Our ship was hijacked and taken to Iran'
item.description: Former crew of the oil tanker Gulf Sky talk publically for the first time about the ship's disappearance.

item.title: E10 petrol: What is it and can my car run on it?
item.description: A more eco-friendly petrol is coming to filling stations - but it's not suitable for all cars.

item.title: Marseille drugs: Child victims of French city's vicious gang war
item.description: A 14-year-old is the latest victim of Marseille's gang war, prompting a key visit from President Macron.

item.title: Covid: How do I get the vaccine and will I need a booster?
item.description: All over-16s can now get the Covid vaccine, and booster jabs could be rolled out from September.

item.title: When will furlough end?
item.description: The furlough scheme, which protected millions of jobs during the pandemic, is in its final weeks.

item.title: Sarah Rainsford: My last report before Russian expulsion
item.description: The BBC's Moscow correspondent files her final despatch after more than 20 years reporting in Russia.

item.title: Theranos scandal: Who is Elizabeth Holmes and why is she on trial?
item.description: The former boss of blood testing company Theranos is accused of fraud and could face years in jail.

item.title: Scotland beaten comfortably by vibrant Denmark in World Cup qualifier
item.description: Scotland's World Cup hopes were dealt a serious blow as they were taken apart by a vibrant Denmark side in Copenhagen to slip seven points behind the Group F leaders.

item.title: Afghanistan women's cricket team: Players hiding in Kabul fear Taliban rule
item.description: Members of Afghanistan's women's cricket team are hiding in Kabul, fearing for their safety following the Taliban's return to power.

item.title: Beaumont hits stunning 97 as England thrash New Zealand in first T20
item.description: Tammy Beaumont crashes a sensational 97 as England romp to a 46-run victory over New Zealand in the first Twenty20 at Chelmsford.

item.title: Evans beats Giron to equal best US Open run
item.description: British number one Dan Evans equals his best performance at the US Open by reaching the third round at a rain-affected Flushing Meadows.

item.title: England mull pace options for fourth Test against India
item.description: England are mulling over their pace options for the crucial fourth Test against India at the Oval, beginning on Thursday.

item.title: Raikkonen to retire from F1 at end of season
item.description: Former world champion Kimi Raikkonen announces that he will retire from Formula 1 at the end of the season.

item.title: England v New Zealand T20: Brilliant Tammy Beaumont hits 97 in England win
item.description: Watch the best moments from Tammy Beaumont's brilliant 97 as England beat New Zealand by 46 runs.

item.title: Afghanistan: How can the West stop terror bases?
item.description: The foreign secretary says the UK will fight ISIS-K by all means available - but what does that mean?

item.title: Afghanistan: Rescued animals 'in amazing condition' in UK
item.description: Most of the 150 animals rescued by "Pen" Farthing's charity are to be adopted by veterans.

item.title: Afghanistan: Joe Biden speech on withdrawal fact-checked
item.description: How consistent is President Biden in his comments on Afghanistan following the final US troop withdrawal?

item.title: Amid violent reprisals, Afghans fear the Taliban's 'amnesty' was empty
item.description: Reports suggest the Taliban are searching for, and allegedly killing, people they pledged to leave in peace.

item.title: Female journalist who interviewed Taliban flees
item.description: Beheshta Arghand, who made headlines when she interviewed the Taliban, has spoken out after fleeing the country.

item.title: Afghanistan: 'Struggle to survive or race to escape' on streets of Kabul
item.description: The BBC's Lyse Doucet reports from the Afghan capital, a day after the last US troops left.

item.title: Afghanistan: UK embassy told Afghans to go to Abbey Gate before suicide attack
item.description: Despite an attack being expected, emails seen by the BBC show embassy staff directing Afghans to the gate.

item.title: Taliban are back - what next for Afghanistan?
item.description: As the Taliban take power after 20 years of conflict, what did the war achieve and what happens now?

item.title: Smith retains individual Paralympic boccia title
item.description: Britain's David Smith likens himself to footballer Cristiano Ronaldo as he retains his Paralympic boccia individual title.

item.title: Becky Redfern: The 'tough ride' to becoming a Paralympic silver medallist
item.description: Becky Redfern said it was "an incredible feeling" to win Paralympic bronze in the SB13 100m breaststroke, just over a year after giving birth to her first child.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Gordon Reid and Alfie Hewett reach semi-finals
item.description: Defending champion Gordon Reid and Rio silver medallist Alfie Hewett both made it into to the men's singles semi-finals.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Who are Great Britain's medal winners?
item.description: A list of the Great Britain medal winners from the Tokyo 2020 Paralympics.

item.title: Which country has won most golds?
item.description: Which country is leading the medal table for the Tokyo 2020 Paralympics? How are Great Britain getting on?

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: What you need to know about Paralympic classification
item.description: From KL1 to PT2 and F11 to SB6 - everything you need to know about classification at the Paralympic Games.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Sport-by-sport guide
item.description: Twenty-two sports will feature in the Tokyo Paralympics - find out more about them all here.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Afghanistan athlete Hossain Rasouli makes debut after evacuation
item.description: Afghanistan evacuee Hossain Rasouli finally gets his chance to compete at the Tokyo Paralympics - and his opponents can't "help but feel joy".

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Eight Great Britain athletes to watch at Games
item.description: From the 'Weirwolf' to a potential swimming star, who are some of the Great Britain athletes hoping to shine at the Tokyo Paralympics?

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Eight global athletes to watch at Games
item.description: From the Blade Jumper to the dancing star and the Tik Tok influencer, meet some of the global athletes hoping to make an impact at the Tokyo Paralympics.

item.title: Afghanistan: Shukria Barakzai's whispered voice notes and dramatic escape
item.description: The desperate messages sent by Afghan politician Shukria Barakzai to a UK MP as the Taliban tried to hunt her down.

item.title: Afghanistan: The 'undefeated' Panjshir Valley - an hour from Kabul
item.description: The Panjshir Valley has been a flashpoint in Afghanistan's turbulent history - now it's happening again.

item.title: Bilal Sarwary: 'The plane hit the tower and all our lives changed'
item.description: Afghan journalist Bilal Sarwary was selling carpets when 9/11 happened. From that day on, everything changed.

item.title: Shot in the head in Angola, left for dead, now a Wetherspoons star
item.description: Cesar Kimbirima fled Angola after being shot four times and spending five months in a coma.

item.title: Michael Knighton: The man who could have bought Man Utd for £10m but walked away
item.description: In August 1989, Michael Knighton celebrated his Manchester United takeover deal at Old Trafford. But the plotting against him had just begun.
